overview: Calcium is the most abundant mineral in the human body and is a major structural component of bones and teeth. It also plays critical roles in muscle contraction, nerve transmission, blood clotting, hormone secretion and intracellular signaling. About 99% of body calcium is stored in the skeleton and teeth, with the remaining 1% circulating in blood and soft tissues where it is tightly regulated.
benefits: Provides structural support for bones and teeth, helping achieve and maintain normal bone density and skeletal strength
Supports normal muscle contraction, including the contraction of cardiac muscle in the heart
Plays a key role in nerve transmission and neuromuscular signaling
Contributes to normal blood clotting through activation of several coagulation factors
Involved in the release of hormones and neurotransmitters and in many intracellular signaling pathways
Adequate intake during childhood, adolescence and early adulthood helps achieve peak bone mass, which lowers the risk of osteoporosis later in life
sideEffects: Excessive calcium intake from supplements and fortified foods can cause constipation and gastrointestinal discomfort in some individuals
Very high calcium intakes over time may contribute to kidney stone formation in susceptible people, particularly when combined with high vitamin D intake or other risk factors
Chronic hypercalcemia from high-dose supplements or underlying disease can lead to calcification of soft tissues, impaired kidney function and cardiac rhythm disturbances
High supplemental calcium doses taken without medical guidance may slightly increase cardiovascular risk in some studies, though findings are not fully consistent
deficiencySigns: In children, prolonged inadequate calcium intake contributes to impaired bone mineralization and may increase the risk of rickets when combined with low vitamin D status
In adults, long-term low intake is associated with decreased bone mineral density and increased risk of osteopenia and osteoporosis
Muscle cramps, spasms or tingling in the hands and feet can occur, especially when deficiency coexists with low vitamin D or magnesium
In severe hypocalcemia, there may be tetany, seizures and cardiac rhythm disturbances, usually in the context of underlying disorders of vitamin D or parathyroid function

overview: Phosphorus is the second most abundant mineral in the body and is present in every cell. Most phosphorus is stored in bones and teeth as hydroxyapatite together with calcium. It is essential for the formation of ATP, nucleic acids and phospholipids, and is involved in acid–base balance and many metabolic reactions.
benefits: Contributes to the mineral structure of bones and teeth along with calcium, supporting skeletal strength
Essential for the formation of ATP, the primary energy currency of cells, and thus critical for energy metabolism
Required for synthesis of DNA and RNA and thus for cell growth and repair
Component of phospholipids in cell membranes, supporting normal cell structure and function
Plays a role in buffering systems that help maintain normal acid–base balance in the body
sideEffects: High phosphorus intake from processed foods and phosphate additives, particularly when calcium intake is low, may contribute to disturbed mineral metabolism and secondary hyperparathyroidism
Chronically elevated serum phosphate, often in the setting of chronic kidney disease, is associated with vascular calcification and increased cardiovascular risk
Very high supplemental intakes can cause gastrointestinal upset and, in susceptible individuals, disturbances in calcium and phosphate balance
deficiencySigns: Frank phosphorus deficiency is uncommon in healthy individuals because phosphorus is widely available in foods
When deficiency occurs, symptoms may include loss of appetite, bone pain, impaired bone mineralization, muscle weakness and increased susceptibility to infection
In severe or prolonged deficiency, there can be osteomalacia, anemia, numbness, confusion and impaired growth in children, often in the context of other illnesses or severe malnutrition

overview: Magnesium is an essential mineral that serves as a cofactor in more than 300 enzymatic reactions. It is involved in energy production, protein synthesis, muscle and nerve function, blood glucose control and blood pressure regulation. About 50–60% of body magnesium is stored in bone, with the rest in soft tissues and a small fraction in extracellular fluid.
benefits: Supports normal muscle and nerve function, including relaxation of skeletal muscle and modulation of neuromuscular excitability
Acts as a cofactor for enzymes involved in ATP production and energy metabolism
Contributes to normal heart rhythm and cardiovascular function
Plays a role in maintaining normal blood glucose control and insulin signaling
Supports normal protein and DNA synthesis and is involved in antioxidant defense through glutathione metabolism
Contributes to bone health by participating in bone structure and influencing calcium and vitamin D metabolism
Adequate intake is associated in observational studies with lower risk of some chronic conditions, including hypertension and type 2 diabetes, although supplementation effects vary by population
sideEffects: Magnesium from food has no known toxicity in healthy individuals with normal kidney function
High doses of magnesium from supplements or medications (for example magnesium-containing laxatives or antacids) can cause diarrhea, nausea and abdominal cramping

In people with impaired kidney function, excessive magnesium intake can lead to hypermagnesemia with symptoms such as low blood pressure, muscle weakness, lethargy and in severe cases cardiac arrhythmias and respiratory depression
deficiencySigns: Mild deficiency may present with nonspecific symptoms such as fatigue, weakness, loss of appetite and nausea
More pronounced deficiency can cause muscle cramps, tremors, fasciculations, numbness, tingling and increased neuromuscular excitability
Severe hypomagnesemia may lead to seizures, abnormal heart rhythms (including ventricular arrhythmias) and personality changes or confusion
Chronic low magnesium status is associated with low-grade inflammation, hypertension, insulin resistance and reduced bone mineral density in some studies

overview: Sodium is a major cation in extracellular fluid and is essential for maintaining fluid balance, extracellular volume and blood pressure. It is also critical for nerve impulse transmission and muscle contraction. Most dietary sodium comes from salt (sodium chloride) added during food processing and preparation.
benefits: Helps regulate extracellular fluid volume and osmotic balance
Essential for maintaining normal blood pressure and blood volume when intake and excretion are balanced
Required for generation and propagation of nerve impulses through sodium-dependent ion gradients
Supports normal muscle function through its role in excitability and action potential generation
Facilitates absorption of certain nutrients in the intestine, such as glucose and some amino acids via sodium-dependent transporters
sideEffects: Excess sodium intake is associated with elevated blood pressure in many individuals and populations, increasing the risk of hypertension, stroke and cardiovascular disease
High sodium intake can promote fluid retention and edema in susceptible people, such as those with heart failure, kidney disease or liver cirrhosis
Very high intakes acutely may cause thirst, transient increases in blood pressure and increased urinary calcium excretion
Chronic high sodium intake may contribute to increased risk of gastric cancer in some populations, particularly when combined with other dietary factors
deficiencySigns: True sodium deficiency from low intake alone is rare; hyponatremia more commonly results from excess water retention, fluid losses or certain medications and medical conditions
Symptoms of hyponatremia can include headache, nausea, vomiting, fatigue, confusion and muscle cramps
Severe or rapidly developing hyponatremia may lead to seizures, brain swelling, coma and can be life-threatening
Athletes or workers with heavy sweat losses who replace fluid without adequate sodium may develop exercise-associated hyponatremia

overview: Potassium is the major cation inside cells and is essential for maintaining normal cell function, nerve transmission and muscle contraction. It plays a key role in regulating blood pressure and acid–base balance and is involved in carbohydrate metabolism and protein synthesis. Most dietary potassium comes from fruits, vegetables, legumes and dairy products.
benefits: Helps maintain normal intracellular fluid balance and cell volume
Essential for generation and transmission of nerve impulses and for normal muscle contraction, including the heartbeat
Higher potassium intake is associated with lower blood pressure in many individuals, particularly when combined with reduced sodium intake
Supports normal kidney function and contributes to maintenance of normal acid–base balance
Adequate potassium intake is associated with reduced risk of stroke and may benefit cardiovascular health in observational research
Involved in carbohydrate metabolism and protein synthesis at the cellular level
sideEffects: Excess potassium from food is usually excreted efficiently by healthy kidneys and rarely causes toxicity

High potassium intake from supplements or salt substitutes can cause hyperkalemia in people with impaired kidney function, those taking potassium-sparing diuretics, ACE inhibitors, angiotensin receptor blockers or certain other medications
Hyperkalemia can lead to muscle weakness, paresthesias, cardiac conduction abnormalities and potentially life-threatening arrhythmias
Very rapid intravenous administration of potassium (in clinical settings) can be dangerous if not carefully monitored
deficiencySigns: Mild potassium deficiency may cause fatigue, muscle weakness and constipation
More significant hypokalemia can produce muscle cramps, paralysis or rhabdomyolysis in severe cases
Cardiac arrhythmias, palpitations and ECG changes can occur, especially in individuals with underlying heart disease or on certain medications
Increased blood pressure and a higher risk of stroke have been associated with chronically low potassium intake combined with high sodium intake

overview: Chloride is the principal anion in extracellular fluid and is typically consumed as part of sodium chloride (table salt). It helps maintain fluid balance, osmotic pressure and acid–base balance. Chloride is also an essential component of hydrochloric acid in gastric juice, which is necessary for digestion and absorption of several nutrients.
benefits: Helps maintain extracellular fluid volume and osmotic balance together with sodium and other electrolytes
Plays a key role in maintaining acid–base balance by participating in chloride–bicarbonate exchange in red blood cells and kidneys
Essential for production of gastric hydrochloric acid, which aids digestion of proteins and absorption of minerals such as iron and calcium
Contributes to normal nerve function and muscle excitability as part of electrochemical gradients across membranes
sideEffects: Chloride toxicity is rare when kidney function is normal and generally occurs only with very high salt intake or underlying disease
Excess chloride as part of high sodium chloride intake may contribute to elevated blood pressure and increased cardiovascular risk in salt-sensitive individuals
In clinical settings, excessive administration of chloride-rich intravenous fluids can cause hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis and impair kidney perfusion
deficiencySigns: Isolated chloride deficiency from low dietary intake is rare; hypochloremia is usually secondary to prolonged vomiting, diuretic use or other medical conditions
Symptoms can include metabolic alkalosis, muscle weakness, twitching and, in severe cases, respiratory difficulties
In infants fed chloride-deficient formulas (historical issue now corrected), poor growth, lethargy and metabolic alkalosis were reported

overview: Sulfur is an essential element present in the amino acids methionine and cysteine and in many other important molecules, including some vitamins (thiamine and biotin), glutathione and various coenzymes. It is crucial for protein structure, detoxification reactions and antioxidant defense. Sulfur intake is largely derived from sulfur-containing amino acids in dietary protein.
benefits: Provides structural sulfur in the amino acids methionine and cysteine, which are needed for synthesis of body proteins and many functional molecules
Contributes to the formation of disulfide bonds in proteins, which help stabilize the three-dimensional structure of many enzymes and structural proteins, including those in skin, hair and nails
Part of glutathione, a major intracellular antioxidant involved in detoxification and protection against oxidative stress
Involved in phase II detoxification reactions in the liver through sulfation pathways
Supports normal function of sulfur-containing vitamins such as thiamine and biotin, which participate in energy metabolism
sideEffects: No adverse effects from sulfur in amino acids in normal protein-containing diets have been demonstrated in healthy individuals
Excessive intake of some sulfur-containing compounds or inorganic sulfate in drinking water can cause gastrointestinal upset and diarrhea

High intakes of certain supplemental sulfur compounds (for example some forms of MSM or other sulfur supplements) may cause digestive discomfort or allergic-type reactions in sensitive people, though typical dietary amounts are well tolerated
deficiencySigns: A specific dietary sulfur deficiency is uncommon and not well characterized in humans when overall protein intake is adequate

Inadequate intake of sulfur-containing amino acids (methionine and cysteine) as part of protein deficiency can contribute to impaired growth, reduced synthesis of body proteins and compromised antioxidant defenses

Possible manifestations in the context of overall protein-energy malnutrition include poor wound healing, thinning hair, fragile nails and decreased immune function, but these are usually due to broader protein and nutrient deficiency rather than sulfur alone
